turn.1: What were the symptoms of Rivers's apoplexy?
turn.2: " These soldiers were known to demonstrate symptoms such as temporary blindness, memory loss, paralysis, and uncontrollable crying.
turn.4: As such, by the time W.H.R. Rivers was assigned to Maghull War Hospital, it was known as the “centre for abnormal psychology,” and many of its physicians were employing techniques such as dream interpretation, psychoanalysis and hypnosis to treat shell shock, also known as the war neuroses.
turn.5: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.6: Rivers himself was a well-read psychologist and so was already quite familiar with Freud, Jung, and other psychoanalysts.
turn.7: Did he have any other theories?
turn.8: In fact, Rivers was quite sympathetic to some of Freud's ideas.
turn.10: As such, Rivers joined the band of doctors at Maghull who devoted themselves to understanding the origins and treatment of the “war neuroses” under the guidance of R.G. Rows.
turn.12: After about a year of service at Maghull War Hospital, Rivers was appointed a captain in the Royal Army Medical Corps, and his two youthful dreams—to be an army doctor and to “go in for insanity”—were realized when he was transferred to Craiglockhart War Hospital near Edinburgh, Scotland in order to help “clean house” following a scandal.
